description: A deciduous tree of the family Phyllanthaceae. It is known for its edible fruit of the same name. The fruit is nearly spherical, light greenish-yellow, quite smooth and hard on appearance, with six vertical stripes or furrows.
healthBenefits: Extremely rich in Vitamin C, a potent antioxidant.
Traditionally used in Ayurveda for boosting immunity, improving hair and skin health, and aiding digestion.
May help regulate blood sugar levels.

potentialAllergies.name: Amla Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Very rare, but excessive consumption might cause acidity in some.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Tropical and subtropical. Prefers hot summers and mild winters.
2. Soil: Adaptable to a wide range of soils but prefers well-drained, loamy to clay-loam soil.
3. Propagation: Seeds, budding, or grafting.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun.
5. Watering: Regular watering for young plants. Mature trees are drought-tolerant.
6. Fertilizing: Organic manure is beneficial. Light fertilization may be required.
7. Harvesting: Fruits are harvested when they turn from light green to a dull greenish-yellow.
growthDuration: Starts fruiting in 3-5 years for grafted plants. Fruits mature in autumn and winter.
sustainabilityTips: Amla is often preserved as pickles, candies (murabba), or juice due to its tartness.
Dried amla powder is a popular supplement.
Store fresh amla in the refrigerator.
carbonFootprintInfo: Relatively low (0.3-0.6 kg CO2e/kg), particularly when processed and consumed locally.

staticRecipes.name: Amla Juice
staticRecipes.description: A tangy and highly nutritious juice known for its health benefits.
ingredients: 1 tsp honey or jaggery (optional, to taste)
steps: Wash amla thoroughly. Cut them into pieces and remove the seeds.
Combine amla pieces and water in a blender.
Blend until smooth. You might need to add a little more water for easier blending.
Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth, pressing to extract all the juice.
Stir in black salt and honey/jaggery if using.
Serve immediately. Can be diluted further if too strong.

staticRecipes.name: Amla Murabba (Sweet Amla Preserve)
staticRecipes.description: A traditional Indian sweet preserve made from amla, often eaten for its health benefits.
steps: Wash amla and prick them all over with a fork. This helps them absorb the syrup.
Blanch the amla in boiling water for 2-3 minutes, or until they soften slightly. Drain.

In a separate saucepan, make a sugar syrup by dissolving sugar in 1 cup of water. Bring to a boil and cook until the syrup reaches a one-string consistency (a drop of syrup between thumb and forefinger forms a single thread when pulled apart).
Add the blanched amla to the sugar syrup. Cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes, or until amla pieces become translucent and tender, and the syrup thickens further.
Stir in cardamom powder and saffron (if using).
Let it cool completely. Store in a sterilized airtight glass jar. The murabba tastes better after a few days as the amla absorbs the syrup.

staticRecipes.name: Salted Amla (Sun-dried)
staticRecipes.description: A simple way to preserve amla and enjoy its tangy taste.
steps: Wash amla thoroughly. You can either keep them whole or cut them into segments and deseed.
If keeping whole, prick them with a fork. If segmenting, remove seeds.
In a bowl, toss the amla pieces with salt and turmeric powder (if using) until well coated.
Spread the salted amla on a clean tray or cloth.
Sun-dry for 4-7 days, or until they are completely dry and shriveled. Bring them indoors at night.
Once fully dried, store in an airtight container. They can be eaten as a tangy snack.
